Late_blight.symptoms: Dark brown irregular lesions on leaves and stems; water-soaked spots that rapidly enlarge; white fuzzy sporulation on undersides in humid conditions; fruit rot possible.
Late_blight.treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides every 7–10 days; remove and destroy heavily infected leaves; avoid overhead irrigation; remove nearby volunteer tomato plants.
Late_blight.prevention: Use resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, improve air circulation, avoid overhead watering, plant on raised beds with good drainage.
Late_blight.supplements: Organic: compost tea, neem cake; Chemical: potassium phosphate, calcium nitrate foliar; silica sprays as adjunct
Late_blight.expected_outcome: If treated early with fungicides and infected tissue removed, foliage can recover and further spread slowed; severe late infections can reduce yield substantially.

Early_blight.symptoms: Small dark spots with concentric rings on older leaves; yellowing around spots; lesions on stems may appear; defoliation in severe cases.
Early_blight.treatment: Apply protectant fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb at early signs; remove and destroy severely affected leaves; maintain plant vigor.
Early_blight.prevention: Proper spacing for airflow, mulch to reduce soil splash, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops and use resistant cultivars.
Early_blight.supplements: Organic: compost and seaweed extract to boost plant vigor; Chemical: balanced NPK and foliar micronutrients (Zn, Mn) if deficiency observed
Early_blight.expected_outcome: Treatment with fungicides plus supportive nutrition normally arrests disease and allows recovery; minor yield loss if controlled early.

healthy.care_tips: Continue regular watering at the base, provide full sun, stake plants for airflow, monitor for pests and early symptoms.
healthy.fertilization: Apply balanced fertilizer every 4–6 weeks during active growth
healthy.watering: Deep watering 2–3 times per week depending on weather
healthy.recommended_supplements: Organic compost, bone meal for P, liquid seaweed for overall vigor; chemical option: balanced NPK if soil test indicates need
healthy.expected_outcome: Plant expected to remain healthy if regular care continues; supplements will maintain vigour and reduce susceptibility.

Late_blight.symptoms: Irregular dark brown spots on leaves that expand rapidly; lesions on stems; tuber lesions (brown, sunken) may develop during storage.
Late_blight.treatment: Apply copper-based or recommended systemic fungicides; remove infected foliage; harvest carefully to avoid tuber damage; store dry and cool.
Late_blight.prevention: Certified disease-free seed, crop rotation, good field drainage, avoid dense planting and prolonged leaf wetness.
Late_blight.supplements: Organic: compost and Trichoderma soil amendment; Chemical: silica and potassium foliar sprays to strengthen tissue
Late_blight.expected_outcome: Proper fungicide program and removal of infected plant parts can limit spread and protect tubers; severe outbreaks may require crop abandonment to avoid spread.

Early_blight.symptoms: Dark spots with concentric rings on leaves, yellowing and premature leaf drop, reduced foliage leading to lower yields.
Early_blight.treatment: Use recommended fungicides during flowering and bulking; remove heavily infected leaves; manage stress (consistent moisture).
Early_blight.prevention: Good fertilization, reduce plant stress, use resistant lines, rotate crops.
Early_blight.supplements: Organic: fish emulsion for recovery; Chemical: foliar magnesium and manganese if soil test indicates deficiency
Early_blight.expected_outcome: Often controllable with fungicide and nutrition; recovery likely with moderate management and limited yield loss.

healthy.care_tips: Hill soil regularly, provide consistent moisture during tuber initiation, scout for Colorado potato beetles.
healthy.harvest_time: 2–3 weeks after flowering for new potatoes; later for storage types
healthy.recommended_supplements: Wood ash for potassium in small doses, fish emulsion for nitrogen, vermicompost for soil health
healthy.expected_outcome: Healthy growth expected with scheduled feeding and pest monitoring; good tuber set likely.

Apple_scab.symptoms: Olive-green velvety spots on leaves and fruit that later become dark, cracked lesions; premature leaf drop and fruit deformities.
Apple_scab.treatment: Apply fungicides from green tip through petal fall and as recommended during wet springs; remove and destroy fallen leaves and mummified fruit.
Apple_scab.prevention: Plant resistant cultivars, prune to improve airflow, rake and remove fallen debris, protect during spring moisture.
Apple_scab.supplements: Organic: composted manure and kelp extract; Chemical: foliar calcium and potassium during fruit development
Apple_scab.expected_outcome: With timely fungicide applications and sanitation, scab can be managed and fruit quality preserved; untreated orchards will suffer decline over seasons.

Cedar_apple_rust.symptoms: Bright yellow-orange spots on apple leaves and fruit; spindle-shaped gelatinous spore horns appear on alternate juniper hosts.
Cedar_apple_rust.treatment: Fungicide sprays in early spring; remove nearby juniper hosts when feasible.
Cedar_apple_rust.prevention: Avoid planting apples near junipers, select resistant varieties, prune canopy for airflow.
Cedar_apple_rust.supplements: Organic: compost and kelp extract to improve tree vigor; Chemical: boron and zinc foliar for fruit set if deficiency noted
Cedar_apple_rust.expected_outcome: Usually low impact when managed; fruit quality largely maintained with early interventions.

healthy.pruning: Prune in late winter, thin fruit for better size and airflow
healthy.spray_schedule: Dormant oil before bud break; targeted fungicide during susceptible periods
healthy.recommended_supplements: Organic mulch, kelp extract; chemical: calcium nitrate during fruit fill if needed
healthy.expected_outcome: Healthy trees will set quality fruit and maintain productivity with standard care.

Black_rot.symptoms: Small brown spots on leaves with black fruiting bodies; fruit become shriveled, mummified and inedible.
Black_rot.treatment: Fungicide during bloom and fruit development; remove and destroy mummified fruit and heavily infected canes.
Black_rot.prevention: Sanitation in vineyard floor, canopy management for airflow, remove wild grape hosts.
Black_rot.supplements: Organic: compost tea and neem sprays; Chemical: foliar potassium and magnesium to strengthen vines, silicon sprays for resistance
Black_rot.expected_outcome: If controlled early, fruit loss can be reduced; widespread infection will reduce yield and quality significantly.

Powdery_mildew.symptoms: White powdery coating on leaves and fruit; distortion of new growth and reduced photosynthesis.
Powdery_mildew.treatment: Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate sprays; remove heavily infected shoots and manage canopy density.
Powdery_mildew.prevention: Canopy management, choose resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen which encourages soft growth.
Powdery_mildew.season: Warm, dry days with cool nights
Powdery_mildew.supplements: Organic: seaweed extract and compost tea; Chemical: calcium foliar sprays and targeted sulfur applications
Powdery_mildew.expected_outcome: Good control achievable with sulfur/biocontrols; yield and quality usually maintained with correct timing.

healthy.pruning: Prune in dormancy and train vines to promote airflow
healthy.harvest: Harvest when brix reaches target level
healthy.recommended_supplements: Compost tea, potassium sulfate during fruiting, micronutrient foliar spray as required
healthy.expected_outcome: Healthy vines will achieve expected sugar levels and fruit quality when managed properly.

Common_rust.symptoms: Small reddish-brown pustules (uredinia) on both leaf surfaces; reduced photosynthetic area and potential yield loss.
Common_rust.treatment: Apply registered rust fungicide before tasseling if severe; monitor epidemic development.
Common_rust.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids, maintain optimal plant spacing and avoid excessive shade.
Common_rust.supplements: Organic: humic acid for root strength; Chemical: foliar nitrogen for recovery and potassium chloride to improve stress tolerance
Common_rust.expected_outcome: Typically low impact when resistant hybrids are used; recovery expected with supportive nutrition and fungicide if warranted.

healthy.fertilization: Side-dress nitrogen when plants are knee-high
healthy.pollination: Plant in blocks to improve wind pollination
healthy.recommended_supplements: Humic acid and compost for root health, foliar zinc for grain filling if needed
healthy.expected_outcome: Healthy growth and good grain set expected with proper fertilization and pollination management.
